title: What is the best PLA filament for 3D printers? - Quora

response.answer_text: The one that works best for you. PLA is a bit of a commodity. There are some really crap filaments out there, but if you take those out of the mix, you won’t find a huge difference between the rest. It’s more about your specific situation and calibrating properly for the filament that you’re working with. (even different colors of filament within the same product line may behave slightly differently) I like Matterhackers for ease of use…it’s very tolerant of different settings. Hatchbox wins for colors and producing very vibrant prints. eSun (generally considered a “bargain” filament) works really well for me and it’s my go-to for bulk printing spool after spool. The trick is to try different filaments and find out what works for you. Every printer/bed/hot-end is slightly different and “best” for one setup may not be best for you.

My daily printer is a Tiertime UP Box and if I use the UP branded filament then I get very consistent results. These machines print at higher temps than most printers in both ABS and PLA and are optimized for these filaments. While worth it most of the time, the UP filaments are pricey and limited in colours so I’ve tried other, cheaper brands. In Australia, I’ve found eSun filaments to work very well and print almost the same as the UP stuff. I stay away from too much experimenting these days as clogged extruders are not a fun way to spend time, and large prints (6–20 hrs) require really consistent filament to finish without glitches.
